Yes, I have looked on life — and in its spring</br>Have felt my spirit buoyant, and its light</br>As the fresh breeze of morn, that on its wing</br>Delights to waft the filmy clouds, that bright</br>Hang in the mild air, beauteous in the sight,</br>In rude fantastic forms — then, upward borne,</br>Merge into deeper shadows all their white:—</br>Thus did my life's young beauty visions turn</br>To deep dark shades of gloom, that now 'twere vain to mourn!

And I have look'd on life — if desolate</br>And bleak to me the view, it mattered not</br>Since I have learn'd to bend me to my fate</br>And have endur'd it, and can endure the lot</br>Which has been cast me — be the rest forgot—</br>I've learnt to love seclusion, and the shade—</br>The beauteous calm of the sequester'd grot—</br>The lonely haunt, for contemplation made,</br>Where the high-arching boughs o'erhung the grassy glade!

And fondly bend my thoughts, GLENFALL!  to thee:</br>Be thou, as erst, the minstrel's lonely theme!—</br>Won by a sad and secret sympathy.</br>My soul turns to thee:  darkly to I deem</br>The vision; somewhat more than mortal dream</br>That comes upon me, in thy wilderness</br>Of lovely shadows, that, in gloom, does seem</br>The fane of melancholy tenderness,</br>Where sorrow finds a charm, that breathes of happiness!

The sun is up in heaven!  his light of love</br>Is o'er creation thrown — as from the eye</br>Of the Omnipotent it shines above.—</br>The sun is up in heaven, and the blue sky</br>Seems bright and boundless as eternity,</br>And all on earth is blossoming and gay!</br>The air breathes balm — the grove sweet minstrelsy—</br>The wild birds shake fresh dew-drops from the spray,</br>Like tears that music steals from beauty's soul away!

The sun is up!  trees, leaves, and flowers rejoice,</br>And gladden up in the lustre of his beam!—</br>All but the brook — the echoes of a voice</br>Now hush'd for ever, rise up from the stream,</br>As on its murmurs ripple:  and the gleam</br>That lights the dark tide with its visitings,</br>Almost the shadow of his smile I deem;</br>For where her ray eternal genius flings,</br>Its essence glows among creation's loveliest things!

Friend of my boyhood! — could my tears o'erflow</br>With their fresh gush of feeling, — could they start</br>As in my day of better thought, — but no!</br>The dark and desolate fountain of my heart</br>Has long been frozen; tears had once a part,</br>And could relieve my woe, — but that is past;—</br>Thou!  who didst claim them all — what now thou art</br>I soon may be; — for thee they flowed full fast,</br>Thou mother of my being! — those tears were the last!

Friend of my boyhood! — could I weep for thee,</br>'Twould be some solace; — for, whilst here I stand,</br>And mark the autumnal bloom of every tree,</br>The cheerful shifting green hues of the land;</br>And see the promised harvest fruits expand;</br>And hear the burbling of the brook beneath,—</br>I pause and shrink, and feel my heart unmanned,</br>To think these yet have life — and that the breath,</br>That warm'd thy gentle spirit, now is hush'd in death!</br>
